title: Boris Johnson risks landmark Brexit defeat as MPs prepare for key vote amid election threat
text:
Boris Johnson risked a landmark defeat tonight as former chancellor Philip Hammond declared that a historic parliamentary rebellion has achieved the numbers to prevent a no-deal Brexit .

Senior Conservatives including Winston Churchill’s grandson told the Evening Standard that they are ready to defy the whips if necessary — despite threats of deselection and an early general election.

Sir Nicholas Soames said he was going to see Mr Johnson today and would vote against the Government on a Bill to stop no deal unless given assurances. Justine Greening, the former education secretary, announced she will join the rebels in the voting lobbies and that she will stand down as MP for Putney at the next election.

Mr Hammond, buoyed by a resounding reselection vote by his Runnymede and Weybridge constituency party last night, accused Downing Street of “rank hypocrisy” and promised the “fight of a lifetime” if No 10 tried to get him deselected. In other developments:

The pound fell to its lowest level for three years , dipping below $1.20 this morning as investors took fright at the prospect of Britain crashing out of the European Union without any deal.

Labour was divided after No 10 said it would call a snap election on October 14 if the Government is defeated — with some senior shadow cabinet members urging leader Jeremy Corbyn not to give his agreement .

Jeremy Corbyn leaves his home in London (REUTERS) More

Downing Street strongly denied a report that Mr Johnson’s most senior aide, Dominic Cummings, had admitted in private that negotiations with the EU were really a “sham”. But critics said there was no evidence that the Government was putting forward any alternative to the backstop.

Asked about threats to withdraw the whip from rebels, Cabinet minister Amber Rudd warned against a damaging Tory civil war. The Work and Pensions Secretary said: “We should consider carefully the consequences of dividing the party.”

No 10 launched a fightback this morning, saying it had examined the cross-party Bill designed to thwart no deal and concluded it would lead to “endless” delays and ultimately to Britain remaining in the EU.

Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab called it “a deeply reckless and irresponsible piece of legislation designed to cancel or at the very least delay Brexit”.

MPs will vote on the Bill tomorrow, provided a cross-party group of backbenchers are successful tonight in an unprecedented “emergency” vote to seize control of the Commons timetable.
